10.78.text: I want to talk to you today about the year of Jubilee.

19.56.text: Al Gordon who is one of the senior leadership team here,

23.24.text: said that as he was praying he sensed the Lord saying to him that

28.16.text: for HTB, 2016 is going to be the year of Jubilee.

35.50.text: and then he looked up what that meant and he saw that, in the Jewish calendar

42.58.text: 2016 is the year of Jubilee for them

48.84.text: The first year of Jubilee was in the year 1367BC

55.94.text: and the year of Jubilee happens every 50 years so

59.86.text: it actually starts September 2015 and runs to September 2016

72.02.text: and a year of Jubilee is a very significant year,

75.28.text: it's the year when people are set free, debts forgiven,

78.96.text: it's a year of God's mercy, God's blessing, favour, celebration.

84.98.text: also in 2016, Pope Francis declared that for the Catholic Church, 2016 is going to be the year of Jubilee.

96.14.text: So I don't know whether I have the power to do this but if I do have the power to do this

101.16.text: I want to declare that for HTB 2016 is going to be the year of Jubilee (the congregation cheers).

112.42.text: So do you want to be part of the year of Jubilee?

133.36.text: And the word that he uses there, the Greek word is 'mélos' and it means 'member.'

141.22.text: So what Paul is saying is

146.06.text: together we represent Jesus to the world

149.92.text: and you are a member of the body of Christ.

156.42.text: The word 'member' has been flattened out

159.76.text: so now it just means, 'Are you a member of HTB?' 'Oh yeah I belong to HTB.'

164.82.text: No, no no. What it means to be a member of HTB

168.32.text: this, my ear, is a member of my body

181.14.text: To be a member of HTB means to be an eye, or an ear,

185.32.text: or a nose or a foot, a part of the body.

189.86.text: You are a limb, an organ, you are vital.

194.30.text: You are part of the body of Christ.

198.50.text: You represent Jesus to the world,

200.52.text: when people come into contact with you,

202.18.text: they come into contact with Jesus.

247.60.text: He's saying everybody's included, Jews and Greeks, Slave or Free

253.98.text: That's everybody, every ethnicity, every nation, every background.

261.78.text: Whatever your background, whatever your ethnicity

265.40.text: anything - it doesn't matter who you are, where you've come from, what you're like,

270.32.text: you are welcome here. We are totally inclusive.

280.78.text: They did a study about health and happiness

284.60.text: Harvard did this study. It's the longest study that's ever taken place

291.08.text: It's taken 75 years. It started in 1938.

295.90.text: They decided to study what leads people to have a happy life

305.78.text: 80% would say, they think it's money

311.00.text: another 50% said that they want to be famous

316.20.text: but when they did this study,

318.38.text: what they did was they took  724 men.

323.14.text: Half of them were 1st year students at Harvard University

327.64.text: - one of the greatest universities in the world -

330.26.text: the other half were poor guys from inner city Boston

339.32.text: and what they did was they sent them a questionnaire,

342.20.text: a massive questionnaire every single year.

347.22.text: Some of them have become factory workers,  some lawyers

349.90.text: some bricklayers, doctors, one became President of the United States.

354.48.text: And every two years, they got this massive survey asking questions about their lives.

359.12.text: Many of the inner city Boston men asked,

361.12.text: 'Why do you want to keep studying my life? I'm not that interesting.'

366.00.text: The Harvard guys never asked that question. (laughter)

372.02.text: The clearest message that came out of this 75 year study was this:

376.34.text: Good relationships keep us healthier and happier.

381.64.text: (Reads from study) 'Social connections are really good for us, loneliness kills

385.00.text: The quality of your close relationships matters.

387.76.text: Living in the midst of conflict is really bad for your health,

390.50.text: living in the midst of good warm relationships is protective.

393.50.text: The people who are most satisfied in their relationships at 50,

396.86.text: were the healthiest at the age of 80.

399.54.text: Good relationships not only protect our bodies,

403.00.text: The good life is built with good relationships.'

407.74.text: They spent 75 years to come to that conclusion

415.32.text: they could have saved a lot of money and a lot of time.

419.52.text: That's what Paul is saying here, it's all about relationships.

429.82.text: You are so close to one another, so interconnected.

438.28.text: And that's the way to find fulfilment,

447.52.text: Second point that Paul makes here is,

456.98.text: The Holy Spirit lives in you,

459.26.text: we were all given the same spirit to drink.

461.44.text: And everyone of you has a part.

463.44.text: There's nobody here, nobody down in the crypt,

469.02.text: nobody watching this wherever you're watching this,

515.62.text: And then in verses 27 - 31, he lists some of the different gifts that people have.

529.64.text: ... eagerly desire these gifts. All of you have gifts and all of your gifts are invaluable.

535.94.text: Where do you exercise these gifts?

539.46.text: You exercise them - it's hard to do it on a Sunday -

542.96.text: You exercise them in a small group.

545.70.text: And I would love to encourage every single one of you to get involved in a small group.

550.70.text: If you've never done Alpha, come and join us on Alpha.

553.22.text: That's the small group that Pippa and I are involved in every single term.

558.58.text: We are in a small group on Alpha. I don't give the talks anymore,

562.74.text: I don't lead the course anymore but I would not miss being in a small group on Alpha

568.70.text: Last Wednesday, it was so moving.

572.90.text: To hear a women, I don't know, in her late twenties saying

578.94.text: until January 3rd, she had never been in a church in her whole life.

584.98.text: Her parents are atheist, she was an atheist

588.32.text: and for the last four weeks

591.58.text: she's been coming to church and she doesn't know about Jesus,

596.68.text: she'd not heard of the cross but already Jesus is changing her life.

602.56.text: It's amazing to have the privilege of that

607.36.text: When we first started here, we ran what is now called a 'Connect Group'

612.40.text: If you're not in a connect group, I would so encourage you to get into a connect group.

616.90.text: I think of that connect group we ran. We ran it for 6 years, in our home

621.80.text: and I think of the people who came to that connect group.

625.58.text: Charlie Mackesy was in that connect group. Charlie Mackesy gave his first talk in that connect group.

631.66.text: Now he's speaking here on Sundays and gives the first talk on Alpha.

636.20.text: I think of Mark and Jo Glen. Jo Glen became the Church Warden here for ten years.

643.40.text: I think of Angus and Emma Winter. Angus, while he was in that connect group,

648.38.text: I remember him telling me he'd had this vision from God.

651.38.text: He was working in the city and he sensed God saying it's like,

656.40.text: he was in a rugby scrum and he was a forward and his job was to get the ball out of the scrum

661.98.text: and pass it to the backs, pass it to the people who would preach the good news of Jesus to the world

667.08.text: and he was to supply the money, the resources and he gave out of what he was earning then

672.06.text: which was not very much but the more he gave, the more God blessed him, the more he got promoted,

677.34.text: the more he made more money, and he gave more and more and more and more.

681.74.text: He's now the treasurer of this church, a great, great friend.

687.02.text: Or I think of Ric Thorpe. Ric Thorpe joined our connect group

690.94.text: and we didn't have a worship leader so he said,

692.30.text: 'well, I'm musical, so I'll try and learn the guitar.'

695.46.text: And he started with two chords

697.40.text: And for several years he played with two chords (laughter)

701.60.text: Actually quite quickly he became the worship leader here.

704.90.text: He became our main worship leader at HTB.

707.30.text: He went on to get ordained and just recently he's been made the Bishop of Islington.

713.28.text: I could go through the list of all the people in that connect group,

717.02.text: I could tell you probably 30 people who are still really good friends of ours.

722.84.text: We made such relationships in that group that it sustained us in our lives

730.44.text: and God-willing in their lives as well.

739.34.text: So you're included, you're invaluable, thirdly, you're indispensable.

780.94.text: Ok, you say, well I don't think I could do what Charlie Mackesy does,

787.80.text: I don't think I could do what Ric Thorpe did leading worship...

791.42.text: those are the bits that you can see but Paul says,

796.32.text: 'don't think those are the most important bits,

799.54.text: the most important bits are, the bits you don't see.'

803.00.text: In a body, you don't say 'oh it's only the bits you see that are important'.

808.16.text: Oh, what about your heart? You can't see that. That's quite an important organ as well,

812.80.text: member of the body. So I can do without the heart because you can't see that...

816.72.text: no, no, no, you can't do without your heart, even I know that,

819.02.text: I'm not a doctor but I can tell you your heart matters.

822.72.text: And so do all the other organs of your body that you can't see.

826.54.text: And actually, Paul says, it's the bits behind the scenes that are even more important

830.74.text: than the ones you see up on the stage.

833.18.text: You see, this is every member ministry.

836.46.text: Where does the ministry come from in the church?

838.90.text: Yes, some of it comes from here but the vast majority of it should be there (points outwards to the congregation).

843.38.text: You are the ministers and each of you has a role to play.

848.24.text: And the ones that seem to be, maybe you think, 'oh that, that's not a terribly important one,' -

853.46.text: actually no, that's a really important one because nobody can see it.

857.24.text: I think of the people, you can't see the people now who are looking after your children in CHTB.

862.18.text: One of them I happen to know who looks after children at the 4.30 service at Onslow Square

867.32.text: is the head of a school, a very thriving school. He works extremely hard

872.82.text: but at 4.30 he'll be looking after a group of 6-11 year olds.

877.16.text: April, who runs the cafe here, she actually runs a jewellery business as well

881.52.text: but she comes and serves at the 9.30 and the 11.30 service here.

885.94.text: I think of one of the people who helps with the Marriage (course) couples and also the concerts.

892.56.text: He was senior partner of one of the leading law firms in the world, serving behind the scenes.

901.64.text: And Paul says, those roles are indispensable and it's so satisfying.

907.96.text: I've a friend who I played squash with for years. He's had real problems sleeping

913.76.text: He came to see me the other day. He said, I went to help in the homeless shelter

917.90.text: and when I got home that night, I slept like a log.

922.86.text: I said, I think you should go on helping in the homeless shelter (laughter).

926.74.text: And he has and the more he's gone on helping, the more he sleeps.

931.84.text: because he's doing what we're supposed to do.

934.56.text: We're not supposed to be inactive members of the body of Christ,

937.22.text: we're supposed to playing a part, playing our part

941.60.text: because we're a member, we have a role to play in the body

944.62.text: and the role of the eye, the ear, the foot, the hand,

953.80.text: I'd love to encourage you - 7am Tuesday morning, people come and pray here.

957.70.text: This church would not be what it is without your prayers.

960.84.text: 3000 people praying in the prayer room, the 24/7 prayer room this term.

967.68.text: That's what makes this church. It's like the fire underneath the volcano.

975.08.text: And it's little things can make a difference, you can make a difference, every day

980.74.text: what you do, you are the body of Christ.

983.90.text: My daughter and son-in-law decided in Advent,

988.84.text: they were fed up with the materialism of Christmas.

991.18.text: So they decided at Advent, every day to give something away.

995.06.text: And they'd make chocolate brownies and give them away.

998.60.text: Somebody admired Bec's sweater so she gave it away.

1001.22.text: My son-in-law Myles, Myles the rapper, he decided that he would offer to wash people's car screens

1011.22.text: but actually what he found was not surprising when you know what he looks like,

1014.74.text: they didn't actually want their cars, even for free (laughter)

1017.02.text: they'd rather not have their cars washed by Myles (more laughter).

1022.90.text: One friend of Becs' called Maggie, saw a woman in Reading with a buggy

1029.06.text: and she went up and explained what she was doing,

1030.60.text: she said, 'you must be tired with a small child,

1032.72.text: here's £5 so that you can buy yourself a coffee. Happy Christmas.

1037.80.text: And then she rang my daughter Becs and told her what she'd done

1040.54.text: and Becs said, 'why don't you put that on Facebook what you've done' so she did.

1046.12.text: The woman who'd been given the £5

1048.54.text: also put it on Facebook and it so happened that there was a mutual friend

1053.26.text: and the two got in touch and this is what the woman wrote:

1130.62.text: This is what Paul is saying, 'look, look at your body,

1135.24.text: if one part suffers, every part suffers with it.

1139.16.text: Ten days ago, Pippa and I were in the kitchen and

1142.40.text: as usual I was helping in the kitchen, unloading the dishwasher,

1146.72.text: (laughter) putting things away, as I do all the time

1150.18.text: and I was taking stuff out of the dishwasher and Pips was clearing up

1155.04.text: I'd open the drawers to put all the cutlery in

1157.24.text: Pips noticed that the drawers were open and just at the moment, neither of us were really paying attention,

1162.80.text: just at the moment I was putting a spoon into the cutlery thing,

1166.42.text: she decided that was the moment to shut the door

1168.76.text: and she was feeling in a jolly moment and she decided that was the moment to shut it very hard (laughter)

1173.84.text: and it came down on my finger like that and I went 'OUCH!'

1177.60.text: and then I started to make a huge fuss about this little injury (lots of laughter).

1182.66.text: I said, 'look, I'm going to lose my NAIL!'

1185.94.text: And she said, 'no, you won't lose your nail, it'll probably go black.'

1189.38.text: Actually, it hasn't even gone black but (laughter)

1195.04.text: I didn't say, 'oh, well that's just my fingernail,

1197.14.text: I couldn't care tuppence about my fingernail, that doesn't count.

1202.22.text: I'm worried about me, the big parts of me, not just my finger.'

1205.96.text: No, one part suffers, the whole body suffers.

1210.68.text: And that's what Paul's saying. That's the community, we rally round each other.

1215.28.text: That's why we pray for you here at the front.

1217.34.text: If you're going through a hard time, come to the front at the end of the service and we'll pray for you

1221.32.text: because if you're suffering, we're suffering.

1223.60.text: We suffer with you. You can come up and we'd love to pray of you.

1228.04.text: That's what we do in a connect group. It means you're not alone.

1231.50.text: When you're going through a tough time, we pray for you.

1234.16.text: This is the body of Christ.

1236.86.text: I saw in The Sunday Times the other day,

1239.96.text: on the 2nd October 2006, Charlie Roberts carrying a gun,

1245.22.text: walked into a classroom of the Amish, you know the Amish community,

1248.92.text: these very devout, wonderful Christian people

1252.60.text: who live a very simple lifestyle

1254.88.text: and this guy walked into a school near his home in Pennsylvania

1260.50.text: with a gun and he opened fire on a class of girls aged between 6-13

1267.98.text: and he killed five of them, seriously injured two of them and the other three recovered.

1274.26.text: But... it was the most horrific incident and it was all over the world news.

1281.84.text: And this guy had given no signs at all, no criminal record, married with a young child

1287.84.text: and when his mother heard what her son had done, she was absolutely, totally distraught.

1299.06.text: And she became, the mother, Terri, became an object of  hatred, as you can imagine, in the neighbourhood.

1305.48.text: Her husband, the murderer's father was a retired police officer

1310.36.text: And every time they went out shopping, they could see people looking at her,

1318.66.text: And what they dreaded more than ever was this murderer's funeral

1324.18.text: because they as the family were going to be this object of hatred

1326.58.text: and because it had been a global event.

1328.62.text: the world's media were there with their long lenses appearing at the funeral service

1334.12.text: and the family braced themselves for the media barrage,

1336.98.text: a hoard of news crews and spectators.

1339.60.text: And as they walked through the churchyard,

1342.18.text: Terri recalls, she could see these telescopic lenses trained on her

1350.34.text: and  the other members of the family.

1352.56.text: And she said, 'we felt so vulnerable, we knew everyone was looking at us.'

1356.86.text: And then they saw this, from behind a shed

1361.26.text: 30 members of the Amish community emerged,

1370.14.text: men in tall hats, women in white bonnets

1374.76.text: included the parents of some of those girls who had been murdered.

1381.00.text: And these 30 people emerged from behind the shed,

1384.02.text: they fanned out into a line,

1388.10.text: between the grave and the road,

1391.24.text: to protect the family from the glare of publicity of the press.

1397.82.text: They formed a solid wall of black around the family,

1400.96.text: shielding them from the onlookers and protecting them from the media.

1405.76.text: They not only forgave, they said, 'look, if you're suffering,

1409.46.text: we're here to suffer with you.'

1411.78.text: If one part suffers, we all suffer together.

1417.68.text: And Paul says, the other side of this coin is

1420.38.text: that if one part is honoured, every part rejoices with it.

1428.28.text: So when you look at that Lookback DVD for 2015

1434.54.text: you don't sit there and say, 'oh that looks wonderful.'

1439.04.text: No, no, no, that's your body, that's you.

1442.68.text: Those are all the things you did.

1444.68.text: 'Oh I didn't do that.' Yes, you did

1447.20.text: because we're all part of the same body

1450.08.text: and if one part is honoured, if Paul Cowley gets honoured by the Queen

1457.30.text: for his work in social transformation, you're honoured because you're part of it.

1461.60.text: Some of you are helping yourselves at the homeless shelter,

1463.96.text: or Caring for Ex-Offenders and one part is honoured, we're all honoured

1468.88.text: because we're all in this together, we're all the body of Christ.

1476.76.text: If you prayed, you gave, if you gave anything,

1480.10.text: if you've given any money, you're part of it.

1481.84.text: It wouldn't of happened without your giving.

1484.40.text: If you've prayed, if you've come to the prayer meeting,

1486.14.text: or you're one of the people in the prayer room or you've prayed on your own

1489.50.text: If you've served in some way, in the cafe... some way on a team

1497.94.text: And when they're honoured, you're honoured.

1501.56.text: So 2016 is going to be, we believe, the year of Jubilee.

1506.84.text: It's going to be a year of great honour,

1508.62.text: amazing things are going to happen, we believe, this year.

1514.08.text: there's a sense of rising momentum.

1517.12.text: I was with some of the church plants on Thursday and Friday,

1520.46.text: Pippa and I went with some of the people who have planted churches from here

1527.60.text: I think of Brighton planted 6 years ago

1530.10.text: now have 1000 people there on Sunday.

1532.98.text: A church that was about to be closed

1540.98.text: they've been asked to plant into a different diocese

1542.98.text: and that will happen next September.

1544.98.text: And then there's a church plant in Norwich

1546.98.text: which is now the largest church in the area.

1550.20.text: There's another one planted into Lincoln, there's another one...

1553.76.text: ...these cities... have happened over the last six years

1558.32.text: and now it's multiplying so this year, 2016, we could well do

1563.78.text: six, sorry... five city centre church plants from here

1568.14.text: that will be resource churches that will then plant all the way around

1573.42.text: Because St Mellitus in Courtfield Gardens

1575.42.text: is training up now 210 ordinands who will be trained

1579.78.text: to lead churches that will then spread around this nation

1585.98.text: to see the evangelisation of the nation,

1589.86.text: and the transformation of our society

1592.12.text: and it's accelerating and this is the year of Jubilee.

1596.74.text: This is the year when we're going to see this happening in an amazing way

1601.96.text: And all the other things that are happening,

1605.96.text: ...just to take one tiny little thing that we do,

1611.12.text: there's an acceleration with all of this

1614.82.text: It's all about giving people the opportunity to meet Jesus

1620.20.text: We are the body of Jesus to the world,

1623.52.text: we want people to meet Jesus.

1627.08.text: Pippa and I had a few days off with some friends

1633.90.text: told us this about a guy who's going to come

1636.42.text: and speak here in a few months time called Giles Stevens.

1644.20.text: He read History at Oxford, he played rugby for Oxford

1647.24.text: but he was a wild guy

1649.24.text: and this friend of ours Trucker described his life.

1653.24.text: He said that he was on drugs,

1662.66.text: he led a very promiscuous life,

1667.00.text: he even tried to hire St Aldate's Church,

1669.00.text: one of the big churches in Oxford for a fetish party

1671.00.text: and was very surprised the Vicar didn't seem to think

1673.00.text: that was a great idea for the use of the church! (laughter)

1675.68.text: So this guy led a really wild life.

1678.08.text: He was very successful in business,

1681.00.text: working for a leading Merchant Bank

1683.00.text: And he was leading this life

1687.58.text: And there were two young women came to stay with him

1690.14.text: And he was trying to have his way with them

1693.44.text: But they weren’t having any of it

1695.56.text: And it turned out they were Christians

1698.86.text: instead of allowing him to do what he wanted to do,

1701.78.text: gave him a copy ofJohn’s Gospel

1711.30.text: And his life was totally transformed.

1713.38.text: And he's now a minister of a...

1715.88.text: well... he's having a huge impact,

1719.40.text: his ministry is a global ministry

1722.08.text: he's going to come and speak here later in the year.

1724.74.text: But when Giles came back to England,

1726.74.text: he went to see my friend's brother who he had known...

1731.28.text: he had known was a Christian for a long time

1733.86.text: and had been a friend of his for some time

1737.30.text: and he went round to see him.

1739.34.text: And Giles, this great big rugby player, well,

1741.86.text: ex-rugby player, ex-wild life, now encountered Jesus,

1746.96.text: he went round to see the friend

1754.60.text: He was angry with his friend.

1756.96.text: Literally he picked him up by the lapels,

1760.02.text: he put him against the wall and he shook him,

1763.00.text: and he said, 'Why didn't you tell me about Jesus!'.

1767.34.text: He said, 'You saw me taking drugs, leading this promiscuous life,

1772.24.text: 'Why didn't you tell me the good news about Jesus!'

1777.52.text: how many people could pick me up by the...(laughter)

1781.52.text: 'Why didn't you tell me about Jesus!'

1785.46.text: Because there's such a hunger out there,

1787.46.text: people are living their life because they don't know better.

1790.32.text: That's why we do what we're doing.

1792.32.text: That's why we run Alpha because

1793.88.text: there are so many people who don't know about Jesus.

1798.00.text: And that's why we're doing the Alpha Film Series,

1800.00.text: we've loads of churches who run Alpha

1804.20.text: but we want to give them better resources

1805.96.text: and we've invested a lot of time recently

1809.86.text: which I think is going to be extraordinary.
